pros: Friendly environment, flexible, agile working environment, supportive management. Opportunities to develop and progress. There is also a real feel good factor of working for a not-for-profit company that is making a positive difference - helping people to build their skill sets and qualifications, to find work - supporting businesses to grow and thrive - it is rewarding.
cons: Not for profit great for reasons above - but can mean salaries are less competitive than the private sector.

pros: Stability diverse agile working that’s it
cons: Stressful low wage no organisation no up skill training opportunities

review_title: A company which looks after the interests of Manchester by supplying Jobs, Training and Skills and Economic  improvement
job_title: IT in Manchester City Centre, England
pros: Nice office environment, Good Pension, good career progression, medium sized business with lots different subsidiary companies to experience and work with. Working with new technology. Fun Team.
cons:
Low Pay compared to industry standard, Senior management does not communicate very much with staff, hardly any or non existent staff training. Staff to I.T support ratio is too high. Unpaid overtime work. 
Overtime pay is very small compared to industry standard. 
Everything seems to be hush hush about the company, when you ask about what is going on.
No yearly bonuses
No year pay rises
No Training - this is a training organisation and the staff in I.T are not trained on systems that they do not know but they have to figure out. This can be dangerous as when something goes wrong it can impact the business because the staff are not fully trained on a system that has been implemented.

review_title: Previous employer, so maybe it's better now
job_title: Technician in Manchester City Centre, England
pros:
Some good benefits, especially the pension
Really good location in the city centre, and free parking if you use your car as part of your role
Diverse group of companies working for growth in Manchester
cons:
The company likes to operate with fewer staff than are needed. Back fills are deliberately left unadvertised and unfilled for months resulting in remaining staff expected to take on extra work and soak up all the pressure from the resulting fallout.
Once you're in, you're unlikely to see a pay rise or the promised bonus, staff who have been there a long time on really poor salaries due to very low yearly increases.
No thanks for coping with extra work load, only critism when things go badly
No investment or training
Very poor communication from management, would often hear about re-organisations and other business changes through word of mouth

pros: nice offices , generally nice people to work with.
cons:
old fashioned in its outlook.
won't spend money on  must needed resources. too hung up on processes rather than getting the job done. The potential to be a giant , but given that you have a hand up your back half the time, its impossible to see how things will improve. often fire people , and the first you know is when loads of people are missing from the office. Loyalty means nothing, I witnessed a man who had worked there 20 + years made redundant who was actually doing a sterling job.

pros: Not many - avoid! It sounds great to start with but sadly doesn’t live up to expectations.
cons:
Targets all the way over quality.
Poor management who aren’t qualified to lead. 
Progression only if you do not challenge work ethics and shut up and up.
Zero support for staff being bullied or placed in risky positions.
Unable to support staff with health and work balance, let alone the clients they profess to help.
Very dodgy practices to ensure  constant flow of money.
Questionable ethics and inability to work within their own values all round.

pros:
- Amazing colleagues who are very helpful and understanding, important in settling in a new job.
- Managers are very understanding and supportive
- The facilities in the office and very good and modern
- Excellent Career Progession
cons:
- Company is big and complex, therefore it is quite hard to understand the company at first.
- Easily to get lost in the head office building, which is vast.

job_title: Careers Inspiration Coordinator in Manchester, England
pros:
Business like working environment
Flexible working
Good facilities
Opportunities for staff internal training
Average pay
cons:
even "full time permanent" staff are  really only permanent for the duration of government contract
Little inter-business unit cooperation
Can be "lonely" among many as many people work across multiple locations
Little or no pay progression

pros: great training opportunities internally and non for profit
cons: Hard to progress or get promoted

job_title: Human Resources Administrator in Manchester, England
pros: People I met due to sharing the same poor working conditions
cons: poor management, salary below national average

job_title: Project Coordinator in Manchester City Centre, England
pros: Agile working for nearly all roles and autonomy on dress and working day
cons: Under-resourced with lack of training and development opportunities. Egocentric management.

pros:
Good work environment
Half an hour early finish on Fridays
cons: Limited technical growth opportunity. Cant think of anything else.
